did.head: DESCRIPTIVE SUMMARY
did.unittitle: Susie Bright papers and On Our Backs records, 1978-2013.
did.physdesc: Audio recordings, correspondence, movie film, photographs, publications, research materials, videos.
did.repository: Division of Rare and Manuscript Collections, Cornell University Library
did.abstract: Records of Bright's work writing and publishing about sexuality, including records of the lesbian sex journal On Our Backs.

bioghist.head: BIOGRAPHICAL NOTE
bioghist.p: Overview: Susie Bright worked for the feminist sex store Good Vibrations, and in 1984 launched the first U.S. lesbian sex magazine, On Our Backs, with photographer Honey Lee Cottrell, publisher Deborah Sundahl, and Nan Kinney. Susie served as the magazine’s editor. An expert on the history of the pornography business and its censorship, she has reviewed erotic movies and written broadly about sexual issues.

Detailed biography: Susannah "Susie" Bright (also known as Susie Sexpert) (born March 25, 1958) is an American feminist, author, journalist, critic, editor, publisher, producer, and performer, often on the subject of sexual politics. Known for her founding role in the magazine On Our Backs, she is also an expert on the history of the pornography business and its censorship and has reviewed erotic movies and written broadly about sexual issues. She is one of the first writer/activists referred to as a sex-positive feminist.
As a teenager, Bright was active in the 1970s in various left-wing progressive causes, in particular the feminist, labor, civil rights, and anti-war movements. She was one of the members of the high school underground newspaper, The Red Tide, and served as Plaintiff suing the Los Angeles Board of Education for the right of minors to distribute their own publications without prior censorship or approval. (Judgement in favor of Plaintiff).
She was a member of the International Socialists from 1974-1976 and worked as a labor and community organizer in Los Angeles, the San Francisco Bay Area, Detroit, MI, and Louisville, Kentucky.
Bright was one of the founding members of Teamsters for a Democratic Union, and wrote under the pseudonym Sue Daniels in both The Red Tide and Workers' Power.
Bright trained with San Francisco Sex Information in 1981. From 1981 to 1986, she worked for and managed Good Vibrations, which Joani Blank had opened in San Francisco in 1977, the second feminist sex toy shop in the country (after Dell Williams’ Eve’s Garden). Bright wrote Good Vibrations’ first mail order catalog, the first sex toy catalog written from a women’s point of a view to a female audience. She founded the Good Vibrations Erotic Video Library, the first feminist curation of erotic films available at the time. During this time, she got involved with a group of artists called "Mainstream Exiles" and co-wrote and starred in two plays: "Girls Gone Bad" and "Knife, Paper, Scissors."
In 1984, she launched the first women-produced magazine on the topic of sex and erotica, On Our Backs, "entertainment for the adventurous lesbian," with photographer Honey Lee Cottrell, publisher Deborah Sundahl, and Nan Kinney. Susie served as the magazine’s editor until 1991. Known as the "Pauline Kael of Porn" Bright wrote feminist reviews of erotic films for Penthouse Forum from 1986–1989. She was the first mainstream journalist who covered the adult industry trade, and Bright was the first female member of the X-Rated Critics Organization in 1986.
She taught the aesthetics and politics of erotic film imagery starting in 1986 at Cal Arts Valencia, and then in the early nineties at the University of California. Her film-reviews of independent and mainstream films and videos are widely published, and her commentary on gay film history are featured in the documentary film The Celluloid Closet.
Bright founded the first women's erotica book-series, Herotica, in 1988 and edited the first three volumes. Susie Sexpert’s Lesbian Sex World, the first collection of her own stories, came out in 1990. She started The Best American Erotica series in 1993, and has edited it annually since then. She published the only portfolio of lesbian erotic photography, Nothing But the Girl, co-edited with Jill Posener, with 30 interviews and photographs from photographers around the world. It won the Firecracker Award and the Lammie Award in 1997. She was voted into the XRCO Hall of Fame, 5th Estate, in 2005.
Bright worked a screenwriter and film consultant in several films: Erotique, The Virgin Machine, The Celluloid Closet, and Bound, and appeared as herself in an episode of the HBO television series, Six Feet Under.
She started a website in March 1997, and began her blog, Susie Bright’s Journal, in 2004.
Since 2000, she has produced and hosted a weekly program In Bed with Susie Bright on Audible, Inc., where she discusses a variety of social, freedom of speech and sex-related topics. Interviews, book and movie reviews are common, as are letters from listeners.
Since 2012, Bright has worked as an editor-at-large executive producer at Audible Inc, and was nominated for a non-fiction Audie Award as executive producer in 2013.

scopecontent.head: COLLECTION DESCRIPTION
scopecontent.p: Records of Bright's work writing and publishing about sexuality, including the lesbian sex journal On Our Backs, that document American sexual politics since 1978 and show the development of her own activism and thinking about sexual liberation. Her collection contains the history of On Our Backs - magazine issues, production documents, and media and reader responses that document the feminist sex wars and censorship battles that defined lesbian publishing in the 1980s and 1990s. Also included are videos and documents used by Bright in lectures and teaching about censorship and pornography controversies, Bright's collection of pornographic films, articles and photographs that document Bright's career, and works by various artists, writers and activists that contextualize Bright's work within the arena of sexual liberation and feminism. The collection also includes material from Bright's activism during her high school career at University High School and early college career in California. Documents detail Bright's work in various organizations,the International Socialists, Teamsters for a Democratic Union, and the Red Tide, that each contributed to the feminist, labor, civil rights, and anti-war movements. Material also covers Bright's experience as a plaintiff suing the Los Angeles Board of Education when University High School administration attempted to prevent the distribution of the Red Tide underground newspaper. Scripts and drafts of Bright's first plays "Girls Gone Bad" and "Knife, Paper, Scissors." Readers used by Bright when teaching her university courses on the subjects of the politics of sexuality and pornographic films. Pieces written by Bright for various publications, whether as a guest writer or as a regular columnist. Also a collection of the media attention to Bright's publications,including the negative and positive responses to her controversial contribution to the Sexual Revolution and Feminist Porn Wars. Submissions for Counter Visions photography project. Issues of On Our Backs, various files pertaining to the business of producing OOB, as well as the Stormy Leather catalog, the OOB 1989 Lesbian Sex Calendar and Fatale Video; and articles that account for the critical and popular reception of OOB as well as OOB's contribution to the Sexual Revolution and Feminist Porn Wars. Personal photographs, letters, papers and works of and by the OOB staff document the lives of the women behind the magazine and their experience working for OOB and attending OOB related events. Also included is a collection of slides from pornographic films. Bright's collection of prints, drawings and collages,notably drawings by Noreen Scully and works by Honey Lee Cottrell; posters of various films and performances; and images from a variety of photographers. Costumes worn by Debi Sundahl as Fanny Fatale for the performance of BurLEZk, a lesbian striptease performance, at the Mitchell Bros O'Farrell Theater. Bright's collection of pornographic videos spanning 1930-2007 as well as recordings of Bright's news appearances, lectures, award shows and interviews. Interviews with Bright. Publications containing articles by Susie Bright or about Susie Bright and various publications collected by Bright.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions:
accessrestrict.p: Box 16 Folders 22-24, Erotic Film and Video Survey questionnaires, are restricted to permission of the Human Sexuality Curator.
Box 25 is not for patron use.

scopecontent.p: Material from Bright’s activism during her high school career at University High School and early college career in California. Documents detail Bright’s work in various organizations, the International Socialists, Teamsters for a Democratic Union, and the Red Tide, that each contributed to the feminist, labor, civil rights, and anti-war movements. Material also covers Bright’s experience as a plaintiff suing the Los Angeles Board of Education when University High School administration attempted to prevent the distribution of the Red Tide underground newspaper. This series also includes scripts and drafts of Bright’s first plays “Girls Gone Bad” and “Knife, Paper, Scissors.”

scopecontent.p: Pieces written by Bright for various publications, whether as a guest writer or as a regular columnist. Bright wrote for Salon Magazine, an online magazine on contemporary culture, under her column “Sexpert Opinion” from 1997 to 1999. From 1986-1989, she contributed erotic film reviews regularly to Penthouse Forum, a journal containing articles on controversial and pornographic topics. Also included in this series is a collection of the media attention to Bright’s publications—including the negative and positive responses to her controversial contribution to the Sexual Revolution and Feminist Porn Wars.
Articles by Susie for the column the Erotic Screen, The Cream of Adult Videos, Adult Video Advisor
Originals from the magazine and additional copies. Mostly for the column the Erotic Screen, The Cream of Adult Videos

scopecontent.p: For Salon Magazine, Susie's final copies.
Submissions for Counter Visions photography project.

Documents relating to On Our Backs magazine. Issues of the publication; various files pertaining to the business of producing OOB, as well as the Stormy Leather catalog, the OOB 1989 Lesbian Sex Calendar and Fatale Video; and articles that account for the critical and popular reception of OOB as well as OOB’s contribution to the Sexual Revolution and Feminist Porn Wars. Personal photographs, letters, papers and works of and by the OOB staff document the lives of the women behind the magazine and their experience working for OOB and attending OOB related events. Also included is a collection of slides from pornographic films.
Published without a volume or issue number.
This issue should have been numbered Volume 3, Issue 1, as such no issue was published as Volume 3, Issue 1.
Published as Volume 7, Issue 1, repeating previous.
Published as Volume 11, Issue 1, repeating previous.

scopecontent.p:
20 color slides of Debi by an unknown commercial male photographer from an interview at radio station KFRC, San Francisco California.
Annotation by Susie: Debi believes that this was one of the many "debates" we did on radio whether women’s performance was "good" or "bad" for women.

Two publicity stills from the video Bi-Costal, first bisexual adult video in the 80s. Directed by Tom DiSomone. Cara Lott is one of the models.
Annotation by Susie: First 2 men, 1 women XXX film ever produced by the mainstream porn industry. The director was a straight liberal who wanted "everyone to get along". It was not commercially successful at the time because of the straight audience, but a lot of gay men bought it.

scopecontent.p:
Pencil drawing.
Annotation by Susie: Debi Sundahl commissioned this original drawing to be OOB’s logo. She wanted something Greek and reminiscent of Sappho. This art appeared on the first issue of OOB, Summer 1984. However, we never used it again in print. This was framed and hung in the office for the rest of Debi's 10 year career.

Honey Lee Cottrell Diamond Sutra Collage

scopecontent.p:
34X25" formerly framed multimedia collage diamond and triangle shaped photos in center, all depicting butch femme lesbian sexuality. The background is mid century sample wallpaper.
Annotation by Susie: Honey Lee made this piece of art for her and Susie as a couple. It hung in their shared home. She was experimenting with the idea of how you can identify lesbian butch-femme culture at a glance. She was looking at how images of lesbians can portray masculinity while still be recognizable as women and as butch lesbians. Features such as how women touch each other with their hands can flag an image as lesbian. Other signals from clothing include women in uniform, men’s clothing, as well as very femme mid-century burlesque fetish wear. One triangle of the piece features a lesbian cop dressed in uniform; she was one of the role-playing guests Honey Lee arranged to partake in Susie’s 30th birthday party. The triangle photo at the 5 o’clock position on the inset is Honey Lee wearing a tuxedo and evening gloves.

did.unittitle: Famous Lesbians Collage by Honey Lee Cottrell

scopecontent.p:
12 black and white photos of and signed by San Francisco celebrity lesbians mounted collage style on foam core. Clockwise staring in upper left hand corner: Greta Schiller, lesbian filmmaker with her cat; Honey Lee Cottrell, headless nude; Roberta "Birdie" Yuspa, in golden gate park; Rachel Williams, shirtless bent on Susie; Trio of Carla DuBois, Mark Chester and Susie Bright, showing tits; Christian Mann and Susie Bright; Linda Feran aka the "Foosh"; Patt aka Patrick Clafilia; Nan Kinney; Gayle Rubin; Jenni Olsen (Jimmy Dean); Debi Sundahl aka Fanny Fatale.
Annotation by Susie: All of these photos were shot in San Francisco.
- Gretta Schuller was the director of Before Stonewall 1984, one of the first films about gay history.
- Birdi Yuspa was the pioneer researcher in Pulp paperbacks.
- Rachael Williams was the first Black Ms International Leather, first Black cover model of OOB and a leader of the Black lesbian community.
- Carla DuBois is a French born dominatrix and fetish pioneer, a leader in the San Francisco leather community and famous for her body work with Fakeir Musafar.
- Mark Chester is a legendary gay and leather community photographer, the photo of Mark, Carla (aka Mistress Cleo) and Susie was shot at Honey Lee and Susie's house.
- Christian Mann is a second generation photographer whose father Carl Mann printed some of the first nudist and homoerotic wrestling mags after WWII and ran the influential Catalina gay video and created Video team, which was one of the first gay Black video industries. Christian was SB's mentor and source for a great deal of education on how the porn industry works business wise and legally or illegally as the case requires. During this photoshoot he confided information of illegal activities to Susie and when she asked why he was confiding, he said "because you make these fucking videos" and meant that making videos, breaking several laws, and making them despite prohibition made Susie part of the club.
- Linda was an aspiring lesbian filmmaker from Austin, who made one lesbian romantic comedy.
- Pat/Patrick Califia was one of the founders of Samois, author of Saphisty, one of the original contributors to OOB and with Gayle Rubin, one of the best known sexual politics theorists to come out of the lesbian community. She's wearing a leather jacket from Olies (famous lesbian bar post WWII in Oakland).
- Nan Kinney, cofounder of OOB and Fatale video seated in front of Michele Deloris. Gayle Rubin, Professor of Women's Studies at Ann Arbor, cofounder of samois, early contributor to OOB, legendary sex politics theorist and historian. Photo of Gayle by Honey Lee is the cover of her Anthology Deviations- A Gayle Rubin Reader.
- Jenni Olsen is former programmer of the SF gay film festival, historic gay film collector and producer, film distributor at Wolfe Video, well known writer on GLBT film and history.
- Debi Sundahl, cofounder of OOB, Fatale Video. Fanny Fatale is her stage name. Legendary stripper and this photo was taken at the Lesbian Burlezk show which she produced for approx 10 years. In total, shot between '86 and '88, this collection of movers and shakers is a pretty accurate gallery of some of the most influential lesbians and radical sex activists of the period. Out of 14 characters 10 are still highly influential in their field today. Honey Lee made this for Susie and Honey Lee, and was a work of art in the house. It was not exhibited or shown to public during ownership.

did.unittitle: Lesbians Who... poster by M. Lloyd

scopecontent.p: Woman's Press. Poster is covered with text, sometimes accompanied by small drawings overall. The text varies in size orientation, and style, but usually appears as if handwritten. The text lists many of the various factors that define the lives or identities of lesbians. The more visible instances include: "Lesbians / On / Motorcycles" overlaid on a drawing of a motorcycle, "Lesbian / Firefighters", with a drawing of a female firefighter spraying a fire with a hose, and "Lesbians / With / Brain / Damage".
Association sans but lucratif. Paris.
Distributes women's culture, Eugene Oregon.
Starring Tere and Caerage, Fatale Films, Blush Productions. Poster by Dale Baron.
Even Femmes Go Down - Morgan Gwenwald. Blush Productions.
Erotic Danceshow for Women - San Francisco. Blush Productions. Poster features Pepper or Peppar, by Dale Baron. Also a print of the photo used in the poster.

did.unittitle: Virgin Machine (Die Jungfraeun Maschin) movie poster

scopecontent.p:
Formerly framed. The American release poster from first run of the movie feature Monka Treut staring Susie bright aka Susie Sexpert, Shelly Mars (right) and Ina Blum (left). Elfi Mikech was the producer.
Annotation by Susie: Monika Treut and her partner Elfi Mcach were German filmakers who came to SF in 87 and were blown away by the lesbian erotic Renaissance scene especially in strip clubs and biker games. Monika vowed to make a feature based on our real lives and came back a second time with a crew and money - no script, just a loose story line, she would direct me with a setup and ask me to improv. Susie's best scene is taking the young virgin to the railroad tracks and showing her a suitcase of dildos. Susie’s other is explaining what the trick is to staying on stage until their 50s.
Images from a variety of photographers covering a range of subjects. Some may be from On Our Backs, Counter Visions, or Stormy Leather.

Costumes worn by Debi Sundahl as Fanny Fatale for the performance of BurLEZk, a lesbian striptease performance, at the Mitchell Bros O’Farrell Theater. The theater was a striptease club at 895 O’Farrell Street near San Francisco’s Tenderloin neighborhood, operated by the pornographers James Lloyd “Jim” Mitchell and Artie Jay Mitchell.

Bright’s collection of pornographic videos spanning 1930-2007 as well as recordings of Bright’s news appearances, lectures, award shows and interviews.

Annotation by Susie: "The AVN awards occurred every Jan in Vegas at the consumer electronics shows. They are the Oscars’ of the adult industry. SB was given this in the context of her critic's role at Penthouse "

Annotation by Susie: "Part of Special group, project or event All Girl Action, lesbian identified Porn stars. All Girl Action. Reviewed in Penthouse Forum Erotic Screen. Following the success of lesbian made video in the early 80s in Northern Cal, a group of out lesbian porn stars and their "dyke daddy" Bruce even decided to make a high energy lesbian video with some of the energetic influence that they had admired in Fatale Video. The piece is phonetic unlike the gentle slower pace of commercial lesbian erotic in the past. There were fisting scenes, but they were cut out. The butches performed in drag. For its time, it was a daring outsider launch for the mainstream biz, and it is the first mainstream release that shows evidence of being influenced by OOB and Fatale. Some of these models were interviewed for OOB. "
Annotation by Susie: "This was inspired by the production Jane Fonda exercise of early 80s. Not the pioneer lesbian production. "

Annotation by Susie: "Christian Mann headed up a successful series called Afro Erotics to appeal to a black market and black actors. Distinguished because it promoted black directors and the characters were presented as contemporary LA San Fernando Valley characters, rather than Southern antebellum caricatures. There are still racial cliches but it is a Genx generation point of view. "

Annotation by Susie: "Christian Mann headed up a successful series called Afro Erotics to appeal to a black market and black actors. Distinguished because promoted black directors and the characters were presented as contemporary LA San Fernando Valley characters, rather than Southern antebellum caricatures. There are still racial cliches but it is a Genx generation point of view. "

Annotation by Susie: "Christian Mann headed up a successful series called Afro Erotics to appeal to a black market and black actors. Distinguished because promoted black directors and the characters were presented as contemporary LA San Fernando Valley characters, rather than Southern antebellum caricatures. There are still racial cliches but it is a Genx generation point of view. "

Annotation by Susie: "Anette Haven, regarded as one of the most beautiful actors of rated X. was an experienced speaker and has a fan club still today. Was politically active as a liberal feminist and animal rights supporter. Starred in many of the more serious dramas and tragedies in XXX golden years. Susie reviewed many of her careers in Forum. "

Annotation by Susie: "Gloria Leonard is one of the middle aged stars of the Golden Era of erotic films and she was a adult industry lobbyist on free of speech activist for decades. Very politically active as a feminist, free speech activist. She was one of the founders of Club 90, the first feminist porn star support group, formed in 1983. She currently lives on big island of Hawaii. Her first feature film with Radley Metzger, the "Opening of Misty Beethoven" was noted as one of the best of all time. "

Annotation by Susie: "Show and tell lecture on the history of lesbian eroticism in cinema featuring ~ 25 clips from 1967 Terese and Isabelle) - 1998 and contemporary lesbian made videos. Was first presented at the gay film festival of San Francisco to sold out crowd in 1998, featuring the original format for each clip 45 mm, 60mm, 65mm, Beta or VHS. Subsequently toured through American University, repertory theaters, British Film Institute, Hamburg and Bern gay film festival, banned in Australia. Susie was inspired by Vito Russo, who did the lecture slide show called the Celluloid Closet before he wrote his book. Future plans: Susie will present this show live at cornell in 2014 and will do a recording of the presentation. Education availability only"

Annotation by Susie: Posthumous biopic on John Holmes illustrious career. One of the most well known actor in porn, despite rep for penis size, Holmes was probably famous at cunnilingus. More for getting women off than Holmes dick size. Interviews with some of costars and directors. The intent was to make a commercial X rated movie, capitalizing on his name, but it's actually a tender romantic portrait.

Annotation by Susie: Anna Obsessed depicts a heroine in genuine crisis and forced sex. High production values and the combination of tragedy and sex made it a controversial film. Susie included in the first Good Vibrations video catalogue and defended its inclusion despite many customer complaints that it didn’t have a happy or redemptive ending. It remains an example of a XXX feature with high level drama aspirations.
